'''Conjugate eye movement''' refers to motor coordination of the eyes that allows for bilateral fixation on a single object. A conjugate eye movement is a movement of both eyes in the same direction to maintain binocular gaze (also referred to as “yoked” eye movement). This is in contrast to [[vergence]] eye movement, where binocular gaze is maintained by moving eyes in opposite directions, such as going “cross eyed” to view an object moving towards the face. Conjugate eye movements can be in any direction, and can accompany both [[saccade|saccadic]] eye movements and [[smooth pursuit]] eye movements.Hodgson, D. (n.d.). The Classification of Eye Movements. Retrieved from [http://www.opt.indiana.edu/v665/CD/CD_Version/CH2/CH2.HTM] Conjugate eye movements are used to change the direction of gaze without changing the depth of gaze. This can be used to either follow a moving object, or change focus entirely. When following a moving object, conjugate eye movements allow individuals to stabilize their perception of the moving object, and focus on the object rather than the rest of the visual world. When changing focus, conjugate eye movements allow for the perception of a stabilized world relative to an individual, rather than the perception of the world “jumping” as the individual’s gaze shifts. Without conjugate eye movements, there would be no synchronicity of the information obtained by each eye, so an individual would not be able to willingly move their eyes around a scene while still maintaining depth perception and scene or object stability.Enderle, J. D. (2010). Models of horizontal eye movements: Part I: Early models of Saccades and smooth pursuit. S.l.: Morgan & Claypool. Several centers in the brainstem are involved. Horizontal conjugate gaze is controlled by the nuclei of the [[Ocular nerve|Ocular Nerve]], CN III, and the [[Abducens nerve]], CN VI, the [[paramedian pontine reticular formation]], and the [[nucleus prepositus hypoglossi]]-medial [[Vestibular nuclei|vestibular nucleus]]. Vertical conjugate gaze is controlled by the nuclei of CN III and the [[Trochlear nerve]], CN IV, the [[rostral interstitial nucleus of medial longitudinal fasciculus]] (riMLF), and the [[interstitial nucleus of Cajal]].Fine structure of the interstitial nucleus of Cajal of the cat. J Anat. 1995 August; 187(Pt 1): 141–150.{{Cite web|url=http://www.opt.indiana.edu/v665/CD/CD_Version/CH2/CH2.HTM|title=Oculomotor Functions & Neurology CD-ROM|last=Hodgson|first=Douglas|date=|year=2004|website=www.opt.indiana.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-20}} Disorders of conjugate gaze typically consist of the inability to move one or both eyes in the desired direction, or the inability to prevent eyes from making vergence movements. [[Conjugate gaze palsy]]: Conjugate gaze palsies typically affect horizontal gaze, although some affect upward gaze. Few affect downward gaze. These effects can range in severity from a complete lack of voluntary eye movement to mild impairments in speed, accuracy or range of eye movement.Ruben, M. (2017, November). Conjugate Gaze Palsies - Neurologic Disorders. Retrieved from [https://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/neurologic-disorders/neuro-ophthalmologic-and-cranial-nerve-disorders/conjugate-gaze-palsies] [[Internuclear ophthalmoplegia]]: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia affects horizontal gaze, such that one eye is capable of full horizontal movement, while the other is incapable of gazing in the direction contralateral to the affected eye.Toral, M., Haugsdal, J., & Wall, M. (2017, June 08). Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia. Retrieved from [https://webeye.ophth.uiowa.edu/eyeforum/cases/252-internuclear-ophthalmoplega.htm] [[One and a half syndrome]]: “One and a half syndrome” also affects horizontal gaze. One eye is completely incapable of horizontal movement, while the other eye is capable of horizontal movement only in one direction away from the midline.Xue, F., Zhang, L., Zhang, L., Ying, Z., Sha, O., & Ding, Y. (2017). One-and-a-half syndrome with its spectrum disorders. Quantitative Imaging in Medicine and Surgery, 7(6), 691-697. doi:10.21037/qims.2017.12.04

A '''cue tone''' is a message consisting of [[Audio frequency|audio]] [[Pitch (music)|tone]]s, used to prompt an action.
In [[broadcast network]]s, a [[DTMF]] cue tone or [[subaudible tone]] was traditionally used to prompt [[local insertion|insertion]] of a local [[TV commercial]] or [[radio advertisement]] by the [[broadcast automation]] equipment at the [[broadcasting|broadcast station]] or [[cable headend]]. This has been replaced in the IPTV with digital cue tones (typically [[SCTE-35]] streams in North America).
Cue tones were also used on [[broadcast cart]]s (cartridge [[magnetic tape|tape]]s) to cue local equipment to start and stop, particularly to cue the [[tape player]] itself, as the tape runs in an [[endless loop]] and often contains several [[:wikt:segment|segment]]s of [[content (media)|content]].

{{Cyborg}} {{Cyber anthropology}} '''Cyborg anthropology''' is a discipline that studies the interaction between humanity and technology from an [[Anthropology|anthropological]] perspective. The discipline is relatively new, but offers novel insights on new technological advances and their effect on culture and society.
== History == [[Donna Haraway]]’s 1984 ''[[Cyborg Manifesto|"]]''[[Cyborg Manifesto|"A Cyborg Manifesto"]] was the first widely-read academic text to explore the philosophical and sociological ramifications of the cyborg.<ref name=":2" /> A sub-focus group within the [[American Anthropological Association]]'s annual meeting in 1992 presented a paper entitled "Cyborg Anthropology", which cites Haraway's "Manifesto". The group described cyborg anthropology as the study of how humans define humanness in relationship to machines, as well as the study of science and technology as activities that can shape and be shaped by culture. This includes studying the ways that all people, including those who are not scientific experts, talk about and conceptualize technology.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Downey|first=Gary Lee|last2=Dumit|first2=Joseph|last3=Williams|first3=Sarah|year=1995|title=Cyborg Anthropology|url=|journal=Cultural Anthropology|volume=10|pages=264-269|via=Wiley Online Library}}</ref> The sub-group was closely related to [[science and technology studies|STS]] and the [[Society for the Social Studies of Science]].<ref>Dumit, Joseph. Davis-Floyd, Robbie. Cyborg Anthropology. Routledge International Encyclopedia of Women, 2001</ref> More recently, [[Amber Case]] has been responsible for explicating the concept of Cyborg Anthropology to the general public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/explorers/bios/amber-case/|title=Amber Case, Cyborg Anthropologist Information, Facts, News, Photos -- National Geographic|first=National Geographic|last=Society|publisher=}}</ref> She believes that a key aspect of cyborg anthropology is the study of networks of information among humans and technology.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=An Illustrated Dictionary of Cyborg Anthropology|last=Case|first=Amber|publisher=|year=2014|isbn=978-1494773519|location=|pages=9|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Many academics have helped develop cyborg anthropology, and many more who haven't heard the term still are today conducting research that may be considered cyborg anthropology, particularly research regarding technologically advanced prosthetics and how they can influence an individual's life. A 2014 summary of holistic American anthropology intersections with cyborg concepts (whether explicit or not) by Joshua Wells explained how the information-rich and culture-laden ways in which humans imagine, construct, and use tools may extend the cyborg concept through the human evolutionary lineage<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Wells|first=Joshua|date=2014|title=Keep Calm and Remain Human: How We Have Always Been Cyborgs and Theories on the Technological Present of Anthropology|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00938157.2014.872460|journal=Reviews in Anthropology|volume=43|pages=5-34|via=}}</ref>. Amber Case generally tells people that the actual number of self-described cyborg anthropologists is "about seven".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://caseorganic.com/2008/11/robots-robots-everywhere-a-field-guide-to-cyborg-anthropology/|title=Robots, Robots, Everywhere – A Field Guide to Cyborg Anthropology {{!}} The World is not a desktop|website=caseorganic.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> [http://cyborganthropology.com/Main_Page The Cyborg Anthropology Wiki], overseen by Case, aims to make the discipline as accessible as possible, even to people who do not have a background in anthropology.
== Methodology == Cyborg anthropology uses traditional methods of anthropological research like ethnography and participant observation, accompanied by statistics, historical research, and interviews. By nature it is a multidisciplinary study; cyborg anthropology can include aspects of [[Science and Technology Studies]], [[cybernetics]], [[feminist theory]], and more. It primarily focuses on how people use discourse about science and technology in order to make these meaningful in their lives. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.downey.sts.vt.edu/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/1995-Cyborg-Anthropology-.pdf/|title= Cyborg Anthropology: Anthropologies of the Body {{!}} Volume 10, Number 2, May 1995 |website=downey.sts.vt.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-09}}</ref>
=== 'Cyborg' origins and meaning === Originally coined in a 1960 paper about [[space exploration]], the term is short for cybernetic organism.<ref>"[https://www.scribd.com/doc/2962194/Cyborgs-and-Space-Clynes-Kline?autodown=pdf Cyborgs and Space]," in ''Astronautics'' (September 1960), by Manfred E. Clynes and Nathan S. Kline.</ref> A cyborg is traditionally defined as a system with both organic and inorganic parts. In the narrowest sense of the word, cyborgs are people with machinated body parts. These cyborg parts may be restorative technologies that help a body function where the organic system has failed, like [[Cardiac pacemaker|pacemaker]]s, [[insulin pump]]s, and [[bionic]] limbs, or enhanced technologies that improve the human body beyond its natural state.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Cyborg Handbook|last=|first=|publisher=Routledge|year=1995|isbn=|editor-last=Gray|editor-first=Chris Hables|location=New York|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> In the broadest sense, all human interactions with technology could qualify as a cyborg. Most cyborg anthropologists lean towards the latter view of the cyborg; some, like Amber Case, even claim that humans are already cyborgs because people's daily life and sense of self is so intertwined with technology.<ref name=":0" /> Haraway's "Cyborg Manifesto" suggests that technology like virtual avatars, artificial insemination, sexual reassignment surgery, and artificial intelligence might make dichotomies of sex and gender irrelevant, even nonexistent. She goes on to say that other human distinctions (like life and death, human and machine, virtual and real) may similarly disappear in the wake of the cyborg.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Cybercultures Reader|last=Haraway|first=Donna|publisher=Routledge|year=2000|isbn=0-415-18378-2|editor-last=Bell|editor-first=David|location=|pages=291-324|chapter=A Cyborg Manifesto|quote=|editor-last2=Kennedy|editor-first2=Barbara|via=Georgetown University Online}}</ref>
=== Digital vs. cyborg anthropology === {{Main|Digital anthropology}}
[[Digital anthropology]] is concerned with how digital advances are changing how people live their lives, as well as consequent changes to how anthropologists do ethnography and to a lesser extent how digital technology can be used to represent and undertake research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://savageminds.org/2012/03/22/digital-anthropology-group-is-happening-now/|title=Digital Anthropology Group Is Happening Now|last=Thompson|first=Matt|date=2012-03-22|website=Savage Minds|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> Cyborg anthropology also looks at disciplines like [[genetics]] and nanotechnology, which are not strictly digital. Cybernetics/informatics covers the range of cyborg advances better than the label digital.
== Key concepts and research ==
=== Actor–network theory === {{main|Actor–network theory}} Questions of [[subjectivity]], agency, actors, and structures have always been of interest in [[social anthropology|social]] and [[cultural anthropology]]. In cyborg anthropology the question of what type of cybernetic system constitutes an actor/subject becomes all the more important. Is it the actual technology that acts on humanity (the Internet), the general techno-culture ([[Silicon Valley]]), government sanctions ([[net neutrality]]), specific innovative humans ([[Steve Jobs]]), or some type of combination of these elements? Some academics believe that only humans have agency and technology is an object humans act upon, while others argue that humans have no agency and culture is entirely shaped by material and technological conditions. [[Actor-network theory]] (ANT), proposed by [[Bruno Latour]], is a theory that helps scholars understand how these elements work together to shape techno-cultural phenomena. Latour suggests that actors and the subjects they act on are parts of larger networks of mutual interaction and feedback loops. Humans and technology both have the agency to shape one another.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Reassembling the Social: An Introduction to Actor-Network Theory|last=Latour|first=Bruno|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|isbn=|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> ANT best describes the way cyborg anthropology approaches the relationship between humans and technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cyborganthropology.com/Defining_Cyborg_Anthropology|title=Defining Cyborg Anthropology - Cyborg Anthropology|website=cyborganthropology.com|language=en|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> Similarly, Wells explain how new forms of networked political expression such as the [[Pirate Party]] movement and [[Free and open-source software|free and open-source software]] philosophies are generated from human reliance on information technologies in all walks of life.<ref name=":3" />
=== Artificial intelligence === Researchers like Kathleen Richardson have conducted ethnographic research on the humans who build and interact with artificial intelligence.<ref>{{Cite book|title=An Anthropology of Robots and AI: Annihilation Anxiety and Machines|last=Richardson|first=Kathleen|publisher=Routledge|year=2015|isbn=978-1138831742|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Recently, Stuart Geiger, a PhD student at [[University of California, Berkeley]] suggested that robots may be capable of creating a culture of their own, which researchers could study with ethnographic methods. Anthropologists react to Geiger with skepticism because, according to Geiger, they believe that culture is specific to living creatures and ethnography limited to human subjects.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ford|first=Heather|date=2012-01-15|title=The ethnography of robots|url=http://ethnographymatters.net/blog/2012/01/15/the-ethnography-of-robots/|journal=Ethnography Matters}}</ref>
=== Posthumanism === The most basic definition of anthropology is the study of humans.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.americananthro.org/|title=American Anthropological Association|website=www.americananthro.org|language=en|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref> However, cyborgs, by definition, describe something that is not entirely an organic human. Moreover, limiting a discipline to the study of humans may be difficult the more that technology allows humans to transcend the normal conditions of organic life. The prospect of a [[Posthumanism|posthuman]] condition calls into question the nature and necessity of a field focused on studying humans.
[[Sociology|Sociologist]] of technology [[Zeynep Tufekci]] argues that any symbolic expression of ourselves, even the most ancient cave painting, can be considered "posthuman" because it exists outside of our physical bodies. To her, this means that the human and the "posthuman" have always existed alongside one another, and anthropology has always concerned itself with the posthuman as well as the human.<ref name=":1" /> Neil L. Whitehead and Michael Welsch point out that the concern that posthumanism will decenter the human in anthropology ignores the discipline's long history of engaging with the unhuman (like spirits and demons that humans believe in) and the culturally "subhuman" (like marginalized groups within a society).<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Human No More? Digital Subjectivities, Unhuman Subjects, and the End of Anthropology|last=Whitehead|first=Neil L.|last2=Wesch|first2=Michael|publisher=University Press of Colorado|year=2012|isbn=978-1-60732-170-5|location=Boulder|pages=1-21|quote=|via=}}</ref>. Contrarily, Wells, taking a deep-time perspective, points out the ways that tool-centric and technologically communicated values and ethics typify the human condition, and that cross-cultural and ethnological trends in conceptions of lifeways, power dynamics, and definitions of humanity often incorporate information-rich technological symbology.<ref name=":3" />

{{Information security}} '''Data-centric security''' is an approach to security that emphasizes the security of the [[data]] itself rather than the security of [[Computer network|networks]], [[Server (computing)|servers]], or applications. Data-centric security is evolving rapidly as enterprises increasingly rely on digital information to [[business process|run their business]] and [[big data]] projects become mainstream. {{cite web | last = Gartner Group | title =Gartner Says Big Data Needs a Data-Centric Security Focus | date = 2014 | url = http://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/2758717 }} {{cite web | last = SANS Institute | title = Data-Centric Security Needed to Protect Big Data Implementations | date = 2015 | url = https://www.sans.org/press/announcement/2015/06/11/1 }} {{cite web | last = IRI | title = Masking Big Data in Hadoop and Very Large Databases | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iri.com/solutions/big-data/big-data-protection }} Data-centric security also allows organizations to overcome the disconnect between IT security technology and the objectives of business strategy by relating security services directly to the data they implicitly protect; a relationship that is often obscured by the presentation of security as an end in itself. {{cite web | last = IEEE | title = Elevating the Discussion on Security Management: The Data Centric Paradigm | date = 2007 | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/4257215_Elevating_the_Discussion_on_Security_Management_The_Data_Centric_Paradigm }} == Key concepts == Common processes in a data-centric security model include:{{cite web | last = Wired Magazine | title = Information-Centric Security: Protect Your Data From the Inside-Out | date = 2014 | url = http://insights.wired.com/profiles/blogs/information-centric-security-protecting-your-data-from-the-inside#axzz3qZi5pQII }}
* Discover: the ability to know what data is stored where including sensitive information. * Manage: the ability to define access policies that will determine if certain data is accessible, editable, or blocked from specific users, or locations. * Protect: the ability to defend against data loss or unauthorized use of data and prevent sensitive data from being sent to unauthorized users or locations. * Monitor: the constant monitoring of data usage to identify meaningful deviations from normal behavior that would point to possible malicious intent. From a technical point of view, information(data)-centric security relies on the implementation of the following: {{cite web | last = Mogull | first = Rich | title =The Information-Centric Security Lifecycle | date = 2014 | url = https://securosis.com/assets/library/presentations/DataSecurityLifecycle-PDF.pdf }}
* Information (data) that is self-describing and defending. * Policies and controls that account for business context. * Information that remains protected as it moves in and out of applications and storage systems, and changing business context. * Policies that work consistently through the different data management technologies and defensive layers implemented. == Technology == ===Data access controls and policies=== Data [[access control]] is the selective restriction of access to data. Accessing may mean viewing, editing, or using. Defining proper access controls requires to map out the information, where it resides, how important it is, who it is important to, how sensitive the data is and then designing appropriate controls. {{cite web | last = Federal News Radio | title = NASA Glenn becoming more data-centric across many fronts | date = 2015 | url = http://federalnewsradio.com/technology/2015/11/nasa-glenn-becoming-data-centric-across-many-fronts/ }} ===Encryption=== {{main|Encryption}} Encryption is a proven data-centric technique to address the risk of data theft in smartphones, laptops, desktops and even servers, including the cloud. One limitation is that encryption is not always effective once a network intrusion has occurred and cybercriminals operate with stolen valid user credentials. Encryption solutions with multi-factor authentication are much more effective in preventing such access. {{cite web | last = MIT Technology Review | title = Encryption Wouldn’t Have Stopped Anthem’s Data Breach | date = 2015 | url = http://www.technologyreview.com/view/535111/encryption-wouldnt-have-stopped-anthems-data-breach/ }} ===Data masking=== {{main|Data masking}} Data Masking is the process of hiding specific data within a database table or cell to ensure that data security is maintained and that sensitive information is not exposed to unauthorized personnel. This may include masking the data from users, developers, third-party and outsourcing vendors, etc. Data masking can be achieved multiple ways: by duplicating data to eliminate the subset of the data that needs to be hidden, or by obscuring the data dynamically as users perform requests. {{cite web | last = IRI | title = Dynamic Data Masking Software | date = 2017 | url = http://www.iri.com/solutions/data-masking/dynamic-data-masking }} ===Auditing=== {{main|Security audit}} Monitoring all activity at the data layer is a key component of a data-centric security strategy. It provides visibility into the types of actions that users and tools have requested and been authorized to on specific data elements. Continuous monitoring at the data layer combined with precise access control can contribute significantly to the real-time detection of data breaches, limits the damages inflicted by a breach and can even stop the intrusion if proper controls are in place. A 2016 survey {{cite web | last = Dark Reading | title = Databases Remain Soft Underbelly Of Cybersecurity | date = 2016 | url = http://www.darkreading.com/application-security/database-security/databases-remain-soft-underbelly-of-cybersecurity/d/d-id/1325216 }} shows that most organizations still don't assess database activity continuously and lack the capability to identify database breaches in a timely fashion. == Cloud computing == [[Cloud computing]] is an evolving paradigm with tremendous momentum, but its unique aspects exacerbate security and privacy challenges. Heterogeneity and diversity of cloud services and environments demand fine-grained access control policies and services that should be flexible enough to capture dynamic, context, or attribute-based access requirements and data protection. {{cite web | last = IEEE | title = Security and Privacy Challenges in Cloud Computing Environments | date = 2010 | url = http://csis.pace.edu/~marchese/SE765/Paper/security2.pdf }} ===Data-centric security in the public cloud environments=== In recent decades many organizations rely on managing database services in public clouds such [[Amazon Web Services]], [[Oracle Cloud]], [[Google Cloud Platform]] or [[Microsoft Azure]] to organize their data. Such approach has its own limitations on what users can do with managing security of their sensitive data. For instance, hardware security appliances or agents running on the database servers are no longer an option. This requires innovative ways to secure data and databases such as using reverse proxy sitting between clients / applications and database servers. The requirements such supporting a load balancing, high availability and fail-over in data-centric security brings additional challenges that database security vendors must meet. {{cite web | last = DataSunrise | title = Data-centric database security in the public clouds | date = 2017 | url = https://www.datasunrise.com/blog/database-security-in-the-cloud }} == See also == {{Portal|Information technology}} * [[Data masking]] * [[Data security]] * [[Defense in depth (computing)]] * [[Information security]] * [[Information security policies]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Big data]]

{{Infobox scholar | name = David Greetham | image = David greetham.png | alt = Greetham leaning on windowsill | caption =David Greetham near window | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1941|10|21|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cheshire]], [[England]] | residence = [[Lenox, Massachusetts]]<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/david.greetham13 David Greetham | Facebook] Retrieved 2017-05-05.</ref> | workplaces = [[The Graduate Center, CUNY]] | school_tradition = [[Textual scholarship]] }}
'''David Greetham''' (born October 21, 1941) is an Anglo-American literary critic and the founder of the [[Society for Textual Scholarship]].
==Career==
Greetham received his undergraduate degree from the [[University of Oxford]] in 1963 and completed his Ph.D. in English at the [[City University of New York]].
[[Marta Werner]] of [[D'Youville College]] describes Greetham as "drawn to texts that spill over the boundaries of genre, that exist in multiple versions, that explore intertextuality, and that complicate in various other ways the notion of text as fixed or stable."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Warner|first1=Marta|title=Post-Everything|journal=Text|date=2003|volume=15|pages=337–349|ref=post_everything|jstor=30227799}}</ref> In his works, Greetham has sought to co-opt "the terminology and practice of literary theory in re-designating textual operations in the guise of ... literature, anthropology, sociology, gender studies, history, political science, linguistics, psychology, [and] philosophy."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Greetham|first1=David C.|title=Theories of the Text|date=1999|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=67Yg06eUaDkC|accessdate=15 April 2015|ref=theories_text}}</ref>
As a theorist of scholarly editing, Greetham has taken up a middle ground between [[intentionalist]] positions like that of [[G. Thomas Tanselle]] and the [[social textual criticism]] of [[Jerome McGann]], maintaining the goal of establishing an authoritative text while allowing the possibility that multiple authorized versions can exist.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mathijsen|first1=Marita|title=The Concept of Authorisation|journal=Text|date=2002|volume=14|pages=85–6}}</ref> In his later work, Greetham has moved away from the idea that an editor can establish a "psychic" connection with the author through which he or she can determine the author's true intentions, instead seeing editing as an occasion for reflections on the ideology underlying scholarly practice.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Werner|first1=Marta|title=Signals from a Distance: Editing, Telepathy, Elegy|journal=Textual Cultures|date=2008|volume=3|issue=1|page=7}}</ref>
==Society for Textual Scholarship==
Greetham was one of the founders of the Society for Textual Scholarship and served as the Society's President from 1999 to 2001.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Society for Textual Scholarship|journal=Textual Cultures|date=Spring 2011|volume=6|issue=1|pages=166–169|jstor=10.2979/textcult.6.1.166|ref=soc_text|doi=10.2979/textcult.6.1.166}}</ref> Founded in 1979, the Society provides an interdisciplinary forum for presentation of research in a number of textual disciplines. Notable past members have included [[G. Thomas Tanselle]], [[Paul Oskar Kristeller]], [[Fredson Bowers]], and [[Jerome McGann]].
==Selected works==
* ''The Pleasures of Contamination'' (2010) * ''Theories of the Text'' (1999) * ''Textual Transgressions: Essays Toward the Construction of a Biobibliography'' (1998) * ''The Margins of the Text: Editorial Theory and Literary Criticism'' (1997) * ''Scholarly Editing: A Guide to Research'' (1995) * ''Textual Scholarship: An Introduction'' (1992) * ''TEXT: An Interdisciplinary Annual of Textual Studies'' (1984)

{{Infobox Organization |name = Enzyme Function Initiative (EFI) |image = efi-mark.jpg |size = |formation = 2010 |status = |purpose = Develop and disseminate a robust strategy to determine enzyme function |headquarters = University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign |leader_title = Principal Investigator |leader_name = John A. Gerlt, Ph.D. |main_organ = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = Five-year [[National Institute of General Medical Sciences|NIGMS]] Glue Grant |website = [http://www.enzymefunction.org www.enzymefunction.org] }}
The '''Enzyme Function Initiative''' ('''EFI''') is a large-scale collaborative project aiming to develop and disseminate a robust strategy to determine [[enzyme]] function through an integrated sequence–structure-based approach.<ref>{{cite press release|title=New NIGMS ‘Glue Grant’ Takes Aim at Unknown Enzymes |publisher=NIGMS |date=2010-05-20 |url=http://www.nigms.nih.gov/News/Results/gluegrant_051510.htm |accessdate=2012-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427131544/http://www.nigms.nih.gov/News/Results/gluegrant_051510.htm |archivedate=2012-04-27 |df= }}</ref> The project was funded in May 2010 by the [[National Institute of General Medical Sciences]] as a Glue Grant which supports the research of complex biological problems that cannot be solved by a single research group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigms.nih.gov/Research/FeaturedPrograms/Collaborative/GlueGrants/ |title=Glue Grants |accessdate=2012-04-27 |work= |publisher=NIGMS |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603062033/http://www.nigms.nih.gov/Research/FeaturedPrograms/Collaborative/GlueGrants/ |archivedate=2013-06-03 |df= }}</ref><ref name=PAR-07-412>{{cite web |url=http://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/pa-files/PAR-07-412.html|title=PAR-07-412: Large-Scale Collaborative Project Awards (R24/U54) |accessdate=2012-04-27 |work= |publisher=NIH/NIGMS }}</ref> The EFI was largely spurred by the need to develop methods to identify the functions of the enormous number proteins discovered through [[Genomics|genomic]] sequencing projects.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Researchers Awarded $33.9 Million Grant to Study Enzyme Functions |publisher=UIUC News Bureau |date=2010-05-20 |url=http://news.illinois.edu/news/10/0520gerlt.html |accessdate=2012-04-27 }}</ref>
== Motivation == The dramatic increase in genome sequencing technology has caused the number of [[Peptide sequence|protein sequences]] deposited into public databases to grow apparently exponentially.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/uniprot/TrEMBLstats/ |accessdate=2012-04-27 |title=UniProtKB/TrEMBL Protein Database Release Statistics |work= |publisher=UniProtKB/TrEMBL Protein Database }}</ref> To cope with the influx of sequences, databases use computational predictions to auto-annotate individual protein's functions. While these computational methods offer the advantages of being extremely high-throughput and generally provide accurate broad classifications, exclusive use has led to a significant level of misannotation of enzyme function in protein databases.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000605 |title=Annotation Error in Public Databases: Misannotation of Molecular Function in Enzyme Superfamilies |year=2009 |editor1-last=Valencia |editor1-first=Alfonso |last1=Schnoes |first1=Alexandra M. |last2=Brown |first2=Shoshana D. |last3=Dodevski |first3=Igor |last4=Babbitt |first4=Patricia C. |journal=PLoS Computational Biology |volume=5 |issue=12 |pages=e1000605 |pmid=20011109 |pmc=2781113}}</ref> Thus although the information now available represents an unprecedented opportunity to understand cellular metabolism across a wide variety of organisms, which includes the ability to identify molecules and/or reactions that may benefit human quality of life, the potential has not been fully actualized.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=130–42 |doi=10.1038/nchembio0805-130 |title=Assignment of protein function in the postgenomic era |year=2005 |last1=Saghatelian |first1=Alan |last2=Cravatt |first2=Benjamin F |journal=Nature Chemical Biology |volume=1 |issue=3 |pmid=16408016}}</ref> The biological community's ability to characterize newly discovered proteins has been outstripped by the rate of genome sequencing, and the task of assigning function is now considered the rate-limiting step in understanding biological systems in detail.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/gb-2006-7-1-r8 |year=2006 |last1=Brown |first1=Shoshana |last2=Gerlt |first2=John |last3=Seffernick |first3=Jennifer |last4=Babbitt |first4=Patricia |journal=Genome Biology |volume=7 |pages=R8 |pmid=16507141 |title=A gold standard set of mechanistically diverse enzyme superfamilies |issue=1 |pmc=1431709}}</ref>
== Integrated strategy for functional assignment == The EFI is developing an integrated sequence-structure based strategy for functional assignment by predicting the [[Substrate specificity|substrate specificities]] of unknown members of mechanistically diverse [[Protein family|enzyme superfamilies]].<ref name=EFIBIOCHEM>{{cite journal|vauthors=Gerlt JA, Allen KN, Almo SC, Armstrong RN, Babbitt PC, Cronan JE, Dunaway-Mariano D, Imker HJ, Jacobson MP, Minor W, Poulter CD, Raushel FM, Sali A, Shoichet BK, Sweedler JV|title=The Enzyme Function Initiative.|journal=Biochemistry|date=Nov 22, 2011|volume=50|issue=46|pages=9950–62|pmid=21999478|doi=10.1021/bi201312u|pmc=3238057}}</ref> The approach leverages conserved features within a given superfamily such as known chemistry, identity of [[active site]] functional groups, and composition of specificity-determining residues, motifs, or structures to predict function but relies on multidisciplinary expertise to streamline, refine, and test the predictions.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=486–91 |doi=10.1038/nchembio.2007.11 |title=Prediction and assignment of function for a divergent N-succinyl amino acid racemase |year=2007 |last1=Song |first1=Ling |last2=Kalyanaraman |first2=Chakrapani |last3=Fedorov |first3=Alexander A |last4=Fedorov |first4=Elena V |last5=Glasner |first5=Margaret E |last6=Brown |first6=Shoshana |last7=Imker |first7=Heidi J |last8=Babbitt |first8=Patricia C |last9=Almo |first9=Steven C |journal=Nature Chemical Biology |volume=3 |issue=8 |pmid=17603539 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1038/nature05981 |title=Structure-based activity prediction for an enzyme of unknown function |year=2007 |last1=Hermann |first1=Johannes C. |last2=Marti-Arbona |first2=Ricardo |last3=Fedorov |first3=Alexander A. |last4=Fedorov |first4=Elena |last5=Almo |first5=Steven C. |last6=Shoichet |first6=Brian K. |last7=Raushel |first7=Frank M. |journal=Nature |volume=448 |issue=7155 |pages=775–779 |pmid=17603473 |pmc=2254328}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |pages=1668–77 |doi=10.1016/j.str.2008.08.015 |title=Discovery of a Dipeptide Epimerase Enzymatic Function Guided by Homology Modeling and Virtual Screening |year=2008 |last1=Kalyanaraman |first1=C |last2=Imker |first2=H |last3=Fedorov |first3=A |last4=Fedorov |first4=E |last5=Glasner |first5=M |last6=Babbitt |first6=P |last7=Almo |first7=S |last8=Gerlt |first8=J |last9=Jacobson |first9=M |journal=Structure |volume=16 |issue=11 |pmid=19000819 |pmc=2714228 }}</ref> The integrated sequence-strategy under development will be generally applicable to deciphering the ligand specificities of any functionally unknown protein.<ref name="EFIBIOCHEM"/>
== Organization == By NIGMS program mandate, Glue Grant consortia must contain core resources and bridging projects.<ref name=PAR-07-412/> The EFI consists of six scientific cores which provide bioinformatic, structural, computational, and data management expertise to facilitate functional predictions for enzymes of unknown function targeted by the EFI. At the beginning of the grant, these predictions were tested by five Bridging Projects representing the amidohydrolase, enolase, GST, HAD, and isoprenoid synthase enzyme superfamilies. Three Bridging Projects now remain.<ref name="EFIBIOCHEM"/> In addition, the Anaerobic Enzymology Pilot Project was added in 2014 to explore the Radical SAM superfamily and Glycyl Radical Enzyme superfamily.
=== Scientific cores ===
The bioinformatics core contributes [[bioinformatic]] analysis by collecting and curating complete sequence data sets, generating sequence similarity networks, and classification of superfamily members into subgroups and families for subsequent annotation transfer and evaluation as targets for functional characterization.
The protein core develops cloning, expression, and [[protein purification]] strategies for the enzymes targeted for study.
The structure core fulfills the [[structural biology]] component for EFI by providing high resolution structures of targeted enzymes.
The computation core performs ''in silico'' [[Docking (molecular)|docking]] to generate rank-ordered lists of predicted substrates for targeted enzymes using both experimentally determined and/or homology modeled protein structures.
The microbiology core examines ''in vivo'' functions using genetic techniques and [[metabolomics]] to compliment ''[[in vitro]]'' functions determined by the Bridging Projects.
The data and dissemination core maintains a public database for experimental data (EFI-DB).<ref>{{cite journal |pages=2545–55 |doi=10.1021/bi052101l |title=Leveraging Enzyme Structure−Function Relationships for Functional Inference and Experimental Design: The Structure−Function Linkage Database† |year=2006 |last1=Pegg |first1=Scott C.-H. |last2=Brown |first2=Shoshana D. |last3=Ojha |first3=Sunil |last4=Seffernick |first4=Jennifer |last5=Meng |first5=Elaine C. |last6=Morris |first6=John H. |last7=Chang |first7=Patricia J. |last8=Huang |first8=Conrad C. |last9=Ferrin |first9=Thomas E. |journal=Biochemistry |volume=45 |issue=8 |pmid=16489747 }}</ref><ref name=EFI-DB>{{cite web|title=EFI-DB Experimental Database|url=http://kiemlicz.med.virginia.edu/efi/|publisher=Enzyme Function Initiative|accessdate=2012-04-27}}</ref>
=== Bridging projects === The [[enolase superfamily]] contains evolutionarily related enzymes with a (β/α)7β‑barrel (TIM‑barrel) fold which primarily catalyze metal-assisted epimerization/racemization or β-elimination of carboxylate substrates.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=59–70 |doi=10.1016/j.abb.2004.07.034 |title=Divergent evolution in the enolase superfamily: The interplay of mechanism and specificity |year=2005 |last1=Gerlt |first1=John A. |last2=Babbitt |first2=Patricia C. |last3=Rayment |first3=Ivan |journal=Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics |volume=433 |pmid=15581566 |issue=1}}</ref>
The [[Haloacid dehydrogenase superfamily]] contains evolutionarily related enzymes with a Rossmanoid α/β fold with an inserted "cap" region which primarily catalyze metal-assisted nucleophilic catalysis, most frequently resulting in phosphoryl group transfer.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=1003–34 |doi=10.1016/j.jmb.2006.06.049 |title=Evolutionary Genomics of the HAD Superfamily: Understanding the Structural Adaptations and Catalytic Diversity in a Superfamily of Phosphoesterases and Allied Enzymes |year=2006 |last1=Burroughs |first1=A. Maxwell |last2=Allen |first2=Karen N. |last3=Dunaway-Mariano |first3=Debra |last4=Aravind |first4=L. |journal=Journal of Molecular Biology |volume=361 |issue=5 |pmid=16889794}}</ref>
The isoprenoid synthase (I) superfamily contains evolutionarily related enzymes with a mostly all α-helical fold and primarily catalyze trans-prenyl transfer reactions to form elongated or cyclized [[isoprene]] products.<ref>{{cite journal |pages=3412–42 |doi=10.1021/cr050286w |title=Structural Biology and Chemistry of the Terpenoid Cyclases |year=2006 |last1=Christianson |first1=David W. |journal=Chemical Reviews |volume=106 |issue=8 |pmid=16895335}}</ref>
The Anaerobic Enzymology bridging project will explore radical-dependent enzymology, which allows the execution of unusual chemical transformations via an iron-sulfur cluster cleaving S-Adenosyl methionine (SAM) and producing a radical intermediate, or alternatively, abstraction of a hydrogen from glycine producing a glycyl radical. The superfamilies containing these enzymes are largely unexplored and thus, ripe with the potential for functional discoveries. The acquisition of an anaerobic protein production pipeline coupled with the installation of a Biosafety Level 2 anaerobic chamber for culturing human gut microbes has readied the EFI to pursue anaerobic enzymology.
=== Participating investigators === Twelve investigators with expertise in various disciplines make up the EFI.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://enzymefunction.org/about/people |title=People |publisher=Enzyme Function Initiative |accessdate=2012-04-27}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Name !! Institution !! Role |- | '''Gerlt, John A.''' || University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign || Program Director, Director of the Enolase Bridging Project, Co-Director of Data and Dissemination Core |- | Allen, Karen N. || Boston University || Director of the HAD Bridging Project |- | Almo, Steven C. || Albert Einstein College of Medicine || Director of the Protein Core and Structure Core |- | Cronan, John E. || University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign || Co-Director of the Microbiology Core |- | Jacobson, Matthew P. || University of California, San Francisco || Co-Director of the Computation Core |- | Minor, Wladek || University of Virginia || Co-Director of Data and Dissemination Core |- | Poulter, C. Dale || University of Utah || Director of the Isoprenoid Synthase Bridging Project |- | Sali, Andrej || University of California, San Francisco || Co-Director of the Computation Core |- | Shoichet, Brian K. || University of California, San Francisco || Co-Director of the Computation Core |- | Sweedler, Jonathan V. || University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign || Co-Director of the Microbiology Core |- | Pollard, Katherine S. || Gladstone Institutes || Director of the Sifting Families Pilot Project |- | Booker, Squire J. || Pennsylvania State University || Director of the Anaerobic Enzymology Pilot Project |- |}
== Deliverables == The EFI's primary deliverable is development and dissemination of an integrated sequence/structure strategy for functional assignment. The EFI now offers access to two high-throughput docking tools, a web tool for comparing protein sequences within entire protein families, and a web tool for composing a genome context inventory based on a protein sequence similarity network. Additionally, as the strategy is developed, data and clones generated by the EFI are made freely available via several online resources.<ref name="EFIBIOCHEM"/>
== Funding == The EFI was established in May 2010 with $33.9 million in funding over a five-year period (grant number GM093342).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigms.nih.gov/Research/FeaturedPrograms/Collaborative/GlueGrants/OutcomeAssessment |title=NIGMS Glue Grants Outcomes Assessment |accessdate=2012-04-27 |work= |publisher=NIGMS |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427104459/http://www.nigms.nih.gov/Research/FeaturedPrograms/Collaborative/GlueGrants/OutcomeAssessment/ |archivedate=2012-04-27 |df= }}</ref>

In [[astrophysics]], particularly the study of [[accretion disk]]s, the '''epicyclic frequency''' is the frequency at which a radially displaced fluid parcel will oscillate. It can be referred to as a "[[John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh|Rayleigh]] discriminant". When considering an astrophysical disc with differential rotation <math>\Omega</math>, the epicyclic frequency <math>\kappa</math> is given by : <math>\kappa^{2} \equiv \frac{2 \Omega}{R}\frac{d}{dR}(R^2 \Omega)</math>, where R is the radial co-ordinate.<ref>p161, Astrophysical Flows, Pringle and King 2007</ref>
This quantity can be used to examine the 'boundaries' of an accretion disc - when <math>\kappa^{2}</math> becomes negative then small perturbations to the (assumed circular) orbit of a fluid parcel will become unstable, and the disc will develop an 'edge' at that point. For example, around a Schwarzschild black hole, the [[Innermost Stable Circular Orbit]] (ISCO) occurs at 3x the event horizon - at <math>6GM/c^{2}</math>.
For a Keplerian disk, <math>\kappa = \Omega</math>.

[[File:Sport - Hartstongue Fern.jpg|thumb|200px|Hart's Tongue Fern sport]] '''Fern sports''' are plants that show marked change from the normal type or parent stock as a result of mutation. The term [[Morphotype]] is also used for any of a group of different types of individuals of the same species in a population. Fern [[frond]]s in sports are typically altered in several ways, such as the frond apex divided and [[Pinnate|pinna]]e similarly duplicated.<ref>[http://www.gardenseeker.com/roses/rose-plant-sports.htm Plants Sports] Retrieved : 2011-07-22</ref>
==Occurrence== Soft Shield Fern ''[[Polystichum setiferum]]'', Lady Fern ''[[Athyrium filix-femina]]''<ref>[http://www.fibrex.co.uk/hardy-british-ferns/athyrium-2/ Lady Fern sports] Retrieved : 2011-07-23</ref> and Hart's Tongue Fern ''[[Asplenium scolopendrium]]'' are known to have around three hundred varieties or sports.<ref name="boyd">[http://www.peterboyd.com/pteridomania.htm Peter D. A. Boyd's Pteridomania] Retrieved : 2011-07-22</ref> Scaly Male Fern [[Dryopteris affinis]] and Male Fern [[Dryopteris filix-mas]] have a number of commercially available and naturally occurring sports or subspecies. Examples are ''D. affinis polydactyla Dadds'', ''A. filix-femina plumosum'', ''A. filix-femina corymbiferum'', and ''D. filix-mas Barnesii'' <ref>[http://www.hardyferns.com/dbase.asp Hardy Ferns] Retrieved : 2011-07-23</ref>
;Lady Fern (''Athyrium filix-femina'') <gallery> File:Lady Fern frond - normal appearance.jpg|Normal Lady Fern frond appearance. File:Sport - Lady Fern frond tip.jpg|Lady Fern sport. File:Sport - Lady Fern pinna.jpg|Lady Fern pinna showing abnormal tips. File:Lady fern sport - underside of frond.jpg|Lady Fern sport showing lower surface with normal sori. File:Chirosia betuleti, Knotting Gall on the fern Dryopteris dilatata.jpg|A Knotting gall on Broad buckler fern. </gallery>
==Characteristics== The frond of a sport may be branched at the tip and at the tips of the pinna, the colour may vary, and variegation may occur; fronds generally remain bilaterally symmetrical. Ferns sports remain normal in certain respects, such as viability with [[Sorus|sori]] and [[Indusium|indusia]] appearing normal. The frond stipe may be a different colour.<ref>[http://www.ferns.rogergolding.co.uk/ferngenus/athyrium/filixfemina.html Male Fern] Retrieved : 2011-07-23</ref>
;Hart's Tongue fern (''Asplenium scolopendrium'') <gallery> File:Hartstongue - Normal frond and tip.jpg|Normal frond. File:Hartstongue - sori.jpg|Underside of fern sport showing normal sori and indusia. File:Sport - multiply branched Hartstongue.jpg|Hart's Tongue sport with multiple frond-tip branches. </gallery>
;Misidentification [[File:Fern sports - insect damage.jpg|200px|thumb|Typical asymmetric frond resulting from likely insect damage.]] Galls on ferns and other physical damage to fern fronds can be mistaken as sports, however this is usually asymmetric, ferns generally being bilaterally symmetrical. In ''Athyrium'' and ''Dryopteris'' species white maggots of ''Chirosia betuleti'' create mop-head galls on fern frond tips that look somewhat like fern sports, however this is physical damage and not a growth form.<ref>Redfern, Page 288</ref>
==Rarity== Ferns sports particularly suffered during the [[Victorian era|Victorian-era]] [[Pteridomania]] ('Fern-Fever') [[Social mania|craze]], when over collecting of fern species included over collecting unusual fern varieties.<ref name="boyd"/>
==See also== * [[Chirosia betuleti|Knotting gall]]

{{primary sources|date=August 2018}} '''Fluxomics''' describes the various approaches that seek to determine the rates of [[metabolic]] reactions within a biological entity.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Winter|first=Gal|last2=Krömer|first2=Jens O.|date=2013-07-01|title=Fluxomics – connecting 'omics analysis and phenotypes|journal=Environmental Microbiology|language=en|volume=15|issue=7|pages=1901–1916|doi=10.1111/1462-2920.12064|issn=1462-2920|pmid=23279205}}</ref> While metabolomics can provide instantaneous information on the metabolites in a biological sample, metabolism is a dynamic process.<ref name="Cascante 67–82">{{Cite journal|last=Cascante|first=Marta|last2=Marin|first2=Silvia|date=2008-09-30|title=Metabolomics and fluxomics approaches|url=http://essays.biochemistry.org/content/45/67|journal=Essays in Biochemistry|language=en|volume=45|pages=67–82|doi=10.1042/bse0450067|issn=0071-1365|pmid=18793124}}</ref> The significance of fluxomics is that metabolic fluxes determine the cellular phenotype.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Fluxomics|last=Cascante|first=Marta|last2=Benito|first2=Adrián|last3=Mas|first3=Igor Marín de|last4=Centelles|first4=Josep J.|last5=Miranda|first5=Anibal|last6=Atauri|first6=Pedro de|date=2014-01-01|publisher=Springer International Publishing|isbn=9783319010076|editor-last=Orešič|editor-first=Matej|pages=237–250|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-01008-3_12|editor2-last=Vidal-Puig|editor2-first=Antonio}}</ref> It has the added advantage of being based on the [[metabolome]] which has fewer components than the genome or proteome.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Raamsdonk|first=Léonie M.|last2=Teusink|first2=Bas|last3=Broadhurst|first3=David|last4=Zhang|first4=Nianshu|last5=Hayes|first5=Andrew|last6=Walsh|first6=Michael C.|last7=Berden|first7=Jan A.|last8=Brindle|first8=Kevin M.|last9=Kell|first9=Douglas B.|date=2001-01-01|title=A functional genomics strategy that uses metabolome data to reveal the phenotype of silent mutations|url=http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v19/n1/full/nbt0101_45.html|journal=Nature Biotechnology|language=en|volume=19|issue=1|pages=45–50|doi=10.1038/83496|issn=1087-0156|pmid=11135551}}</ref>
Fluxomics falls within the field of [[systems biology]] which developed with the appearance of high throughput technologies.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Aon|first=Miguel A.|last2=Cortassa|first2=Sonia|date=2015-07-22|title=Systems Biology of the Fluxome|url=http://www.mdpi.com/2227-9717/3/3/607|journal=Processes|language=en|volume=3|issue=3|pages=607–618|doi=10.3390/pr3030607}}</ref> Systems biology recognizes the complexity of biological systems and has the broader goal of explaining and predicting this complex behavior.<ref name="Cascante 67–82"/>
== Metabolic flux == Metabolic flux refers to the rate of metabolite conversion in a metabolic network.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3">{{cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006349514030690|title=From Metabolomics to Fluxomics: A Computational Procedure to Translate Metabolite Profiles into Metabolic Fluxes|access-date=2016-04-11|doi=10.1016/j.bpj.2014.11.1857|volume=108|issue=1|pages=163–172|journal=Biophysical Journal|pmid=25564863|pmc=4286601 | last1 = Cortassa | first1 = S | last2 = Caceres | first2 = V | last3 = Bell | first3 = LN | last4 = O'Rourke | first4 = B | last5 = Paolocci | first5 = N | last6 = Aon | first6 = MA|year=2015}}</ref> For a reaction this rate is a function of both enzyme abundance and enzyme activity.<ref name=":1" /> Enzyme concentration is itself a function of transcriptional and translational regulation in addition to the stability of the protein.<ref name=":1" /> Enzyme activity is affected by the kinetic parameters of the enzyme, the substrate concentrations, the product concentrations, and the effector molecules concentration.<ref name=":1" /> The genomic and environmental effects on metabolic flux are what determine healthy or diseased phenotype.<ref name=":3" />
== Fluxome == Similar to genome, transcriptome, proteome, and metabolome, the fluxome is defined as the complete set of metabolic fluxes in a cell.<ref name=":2" /> However, unlike the others the fluxome is a dynamic representation of the phenotype.<ref name=":2" /> This is due to the fluxome resulting from the interactions of the metabolome, genome, transcriptome, proteome, post-translational modifications and the environment.<ref name=":2" />
== Flux analysis technologies == Two important technologies are [[flux balance analysis]] (FBA) and <sup>13</sup>C-fluxomics. In FBA metabolic fluxes are estimated by first representing the metabolic reactions of a metabolic network in a numerical matrix containing the stoichiometric coefficients of each reaction.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Orth|first=Jeffrey D.|last2=Thiele|first2=Ines|last3=Palsson|first3=Bernhard Ø|date=2010-03-01|title=What is flux balance analysis?|url=http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v28/n3/full/nbt.1614.html|journal=Nature Biotechnology|language=en|volume=28|issue=3|pages=245–248|doi=10.1038/nbt.1614|issn=1087-0156|pmc=3108565|pmid=20212490}}</ref> The stoichiometric coefficients constrain the system model and are why FBA is only applicable to steady state conditions.<ref name=":4" /> Additional constraints can be imposed.<ref name=":4" /> By providing constraints the possible set of solutions to the system are reduced. Following the addition of constraints the system model is optimized.<ref name=":4" /> Flux-balance analysis resources include the BIGG database,<ref name="KingLu2016">{{cite journal|last1=King|first1=Zachary A.|last2=Lu|first2=Justin|last3=Dräger|first3=Andreas|last4=Miller|first4=Philip|last5=Federowicz|first5=Stephen|last6=Lerman|first6=Joshua A.|last7=Ebrahim|first7=Ali|last8=Palsson|first8=Bernhard O.|last9=Lewis|first9=Nathan E.|title=BiGG Models: A platform for integrating, standardizing and sharing genome-scale models|journal=Nucleic Acids Research|volume=44|issue=D1|year=2016|pages=D515–D522|issn=0305-1048|doi=10.1093/nar/gkv1049|pmid=26476456|pmc=4702785}}</ref> the COBRA toolbox,<ref name="SchellenbergerQue2011">{{cite journal|last1=Schellenberger|first1=Jan|last2=Que|first2=Richard|last3=Fleming|first3=Ronan M T|last4=Thiele|first4=Ines|last5=Orth|first5=Jeffrey D|last6=Feist|first6=Adam M|last7=Zielinski|first7=Daniel C|last8=Bordbar|first8=Aarash|last9=Lewis|first9=Nathan E|last10=Rahmanian|first10=Sorena|last11=Kang|first11=Joseph|last12=Hyduke|first12=Daniel R|last13=Palsson|first13=Bernhard Ø|title=Quantitative prediction of cellular metabolism with constraint-based models: the COBRA Toolbox v2.0|journal=Nature Protocols|volume=6|issue=9|year=2011|pages=1290–1307|issn=1754-2189|doi=10.1038/nprot.2011.308|pmid=21886097|pmc=3319681}}</ref> and FASIMU.<ref name="HoppeHoffmann2011">{{cite journal|last1=Hoppe|first1=Andreas|last2=Hoffmann|first2=Sabrina|last3=Gerasch|first3=Andreas|last4=Gille|first4=Christoph|last5=Holzhütter|first5=Hermann-Georg|title=FASIMU: flexible software for flux-balance computation series in large metabolic networks|journal=BMC Bioinformatics|volume=12|issue=1|year=2011|pages=28|issn=1471-2105|doi=10.1186/1471-2105-12-28|pmid=21255455|pmc=3038154}}</ref>
In <sup>13</sup>C-fluxomics, metabolic precursors are enriched with <sup>13</sup>C before being introduced to the system.<ref name=":5">{{cite journal | last1 = Krömer | first1 = J. | last2 = Quek | first2 = L. E. | last3 = Nielsen | first3 = L. | year = 2009 | title = 13C-Fluxomics: a tool for measuring metabolic phenotypes | url = | journal = Aust Biochem | volume = 40 | issue = 3| pages = 17–20 }}</ref> Using an imaging technique such as mass spectrometry or nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy the level of incorporation of <sup>13</sup>C into metabolites can be measured and with stoichiometry the metabolic fluxes can be estimated.<ref name=":5" />
==Stoichiometric and kinetic paradigms== A number of different methods, broadly divided into [[stoichiometric]] and [[Chemical kinetics|kinetic]] paradigms.
Within the stoichiometric paradigm, a number of relatively simple linear algebra methods use restricted [[metabolic network]]s or genome-scale [[metabolic network modelling|metabolic network models]] to perform [[flux balance analysis]] and the array of techniques derived from it. These linear equations are useful for steady state conditions. Dynamic methods are not yet usable.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Fluxomics – connecting 'omics analysis and phenotypes|journal = Environmental Microbiology|date = 2013-07-01|issn = 1462-2920|pages = 1901–1916|volume = 15|issue = 7|doi = 10.1111/1462-2920.12064|language = en|first = Gal|last = Winter|first2 = Jens O.|last2 = Krömer|pmid=23279205}}</ref> On the more experimental side, [[metabolic flux analysis]] allows the empirical estimation of reaction rates by [[Isotopic labeling|stable isotope labelling]].
Within the kinetic paradigm, kinetic modelling of metabolic networks can be purely theoretical, exploring the potential space of dynamic metabolic fluxes under perturbations away from steady state using formalisms such as [[biochemical systems theory]]. Such explorations are most informative when accompanied by empirical measurements of the system under study following actual perturbations, as is the case in [[metabolic control analysis]].<ref>{{Cite book| last1 = Demin | first1 = O. | last2 = Goryanin | first2 = I. | title = Kinetic Modelling in Systems Biology | year = 2010 | publisher = Taylor and Francis | isbn = 9781420011661 }}</ref>
==Constraint based reconstruction and analysis== Collected methods in fluxomics have been described as "COBRA" methods, for ''co''nstraint ''b''ased ''r''econstruction and ''a''nalysis. A number of software tools and environments have been created for this purpose.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Klamt | first1 = S. | last2 = Saez-Rodriguez | first2 = J. | last3 = Gilles | first3 = E. D. | title = Structural and functional analysis of cellular networks with CellNetAnalyzer | journal = BMC Systems Biology | volume = 1 | pages = 2 | year = 2007 | doi = 10.1186/1752-0509-1-2 | pmid = 17408509 | pmc =1847467 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Boele | first1 = J. | last2 = Olivier | first2 = B. G. | last3 = Teusink | first3 = B. | title = FAME, the Flux Analysis and Modeling Environment | doi = 10.1186/1752-0509-6-8 | journal = BMC Systems Biology | volume = 6 | pages = 8 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22289213 | pmc =3317868 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Rocha | first1 = I. | last2 = Maia | first2 = P. | last3 = Evangelista | first3 = P. | last4 = Vilaça | first4 = P. | last5 = Soares | first5 = S. O. | last6 = Pinto | first6 = J. P. | last7 = Nielsen | first7 = J. | last8 = Patil | first8 = K. R. | last9 = Ferreira | first9 = E. N. C. | last10 = Rocha | first10 = M. | title = OptFlux: An open-source software platform for in silico metabolic engineering | doi = 10.1186/1752-0509-4-45 | journal = BMC Systems Biology | volume = 4 | pages = 45 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20403172 | pmc =2864236 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Grafahrend-Belau | first1 = E. | last2 = Klukas | first2 = C. | last3 = Junker | first3 = B. H. | last4 = Schreiber | first4 = F. | title = FBA-SimVis: Interactive visualization of constraint-based metabolic models | doi = 10.1093/bioinformatics/btp408 | journal = Bioinformatics | volume = 25 | issue = 20 | pages = 2755–2757 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19578041 | pmc =2759546 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Schellenberger | first1 = J. | last2 = Que | first2 = R. | last3 = Fleming | first3 = R. M. T. | last4 = Thiele | first4 = I. | last5 = Orth | first5 = J. D. | last6 = Feist | first6 = A. M. | last7 = Zielinski | first7 = D. C. | last8 = Bordbar | first8 = A. | last9 = Lewis | first9 = N. E. | last10 = Rahmanian | first10 = S. | last11 = Kang | first11 = J. | last12 = Hyduke | first12 = D. R. | last13 = Palsson | first13 = B. Ø. | title = Quantitative prediction of cellular metabolism with constraint-based models: The COBRA Toolbox v2.0 | doi = 10.1038/nprot.2011.308 | journal = Nature Protocols | volume = 6 | issue = 9 | pages = 1290–1307 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21886097 | pmc =3319681 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Agren | first1 = R. | last2 = Liu | first2 = L. | last3 = Shoaie | first3 = S. | last4 = Vongsangnak | first4 = W. | last5 = Nookaew | first5 = I. | last6 = Nielsen | first6 = J. | editor1-last = Maranas | editor1-first = Costas D | title = The RAVEN Toolbox and Its Use for Generating a Genome-scale Metabolic Model for Penicillium chrysogenum | doi = 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1002980 | journal = PLoS Computational Biology | volume = 9 | issue = 3 | pages = e1002980 | year = 2013 | pmid = 23555215 | pmc =3605104 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Mendes | first1 = P. | last2 = Hoops | first2 = S. | last3 = Sahle | first3 = S. | last4 = Gauges | first4 = R. | last5 = Dada | first5 = J. | last6 = Kummer | first6 = U. | chapter = Computational Modeling of Biochemical Networks Using COPASI | doi = 10.1007/978-1-59745-525-1_2 | title = Systems Biology | series = Methods in Molecular Biology | volume = 500 | pages = 17–59 | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-1-934115-64-0 | pmid = 19399433 | pmc = }}</ref>
Although it can only be measured indirectly, [[Flux (metabolism)|metabolic flux]] is the critical link between genes, proteins and the observable phenotype. This is due to the fluxome integrating mass-energy, information, and signaling networks.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Systems Biology of the Fluxome|url = http://www.mdpi.com/2227-9717/3/3/607|journal = Processes|date = 2015-07-22|pages = 607–618|volume = 3|issue = 3|doi = 10.3390/pr3030607|language = en|first = Miguel A.|last = Aon|first2 = Sonia|last2 = Cortassa}}</ref> Fluxomics has the potential to provide a quantifiable representation of the effect the environment has on the phenotype because the fluxome describes the genome environment interaction.<ref name=":0" /> In the fields of metabolic engineering<ref name="Kildegaard-2013">{{Cite journal | last1 = Kildegaard | first1 = HF. | last2 = Baycin-Hizal | first2 = D. | last3 = Lewis | first3 = NE. | last4 = Betenbaugh | first4 = MJ. | title = The emerging CHO systems biology era: harnessing the 'omics revolution for biotechnology | journal = Curr Opin Biotechnol | volume = 24| issue = 6| pages = 1102–7|date=Mar 2013 | doi = 10.1016/j.copbio.2013.02.007 | pmid = 23523260 | url = http://orbit.dtu.dk/en/publications/the-emerging-cho-systems-biology-era-harnessing-the-omics-revolution-for-biotechnology(3d14cbfe-7a58-4483-8e29-db98b61fd906).html }}</ref> and systems biology,<ref name="Carlson-2012">{{Cite book | last1 = Carlson | first1 = RP. | last2 = Oshota | first2 = OJ. | last3 = Taffs | first3 = RL. | title = Systems analysis of microbial adaptations to simultaneous stresses | journal = Subcell Biochem | volume = 64 | issue = | pages = 139–57 | month = | year = 2012 | doi = 10.1007/978-94-007-5055-5_7 | pmid = 23080249 | series = Subcellular Biochemistry | isbn = 978-94-007-5054-8 }}</ref> fluxomic methods are considered a key enabling technology due to their unique position in the ontology of biological processes, allowing genome scale stoichiometric models to act as a framework for the integration of diverse biological datasets.<ref name="Duarte-2007">{{Cite journal | last1 = Duarte | first1 = NC. | last2 = Becker | first2 = SA. | last3 = Jamshidi | first3 = N. | last4 = Thiele | first4 = I. | last5 = Mo | first5 = ML. | last6 = Vo | first6 = TD. | last7 = Srivas | first7 = R. | last8 = Palsson | first8 = BØ. | title = Global reconstruction of the human metabolic network based on genomic and bibliomic data | journal = Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A | volume = 104 | issue = 6 | pages = 1777–82 |date=Feb 2007 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0610772104 | pmid = 17267599 | pmc=1794290}}</ref>
== Examples of use in research == One potential application of fluxomic techniques is in drug design. Rama et al.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Raman|first=Karthik|last2=Rajagopalan|first2=Preethi|last3=Chandra|first3=Nagasuma|title=Flux Balance Analysis of Mycolic Acid Pathway: Targets for Anti-Tubercular Drugs|journal=PLoS Computational Biology|volume=1|issue=5|doi=10.1371/journal.pcbi.0010046|pmc=1246807|pmid=16261191|pages=e46|year=2005}}</ref> used FBA to study the mycolic acid pathway in ''Mycobacterium tuberculosis''. Mycolic acids are known to be important to ''M. tuberculosis'' survival and as such its pathway has been studied extensively.<ref name=":6" /> This allowed the construction of a model of the pathway and for FBA to analyze it. The results of this found multiple possible drug targets for future investigation.
FBA was used to analyze the metabolic networks of multidrug-resistant ''Staphylococcus aureus''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=Deok-Sun|last2=Burd|first2=Henry|last3=Liu|first3=Jiangxia|last4=Almaas|first4=Eivind|last5=Wiest|first5=Olaf|last6=Barabási|first6=Albert-László|last7=Oltvai|first7=Zoltán N.|last8=Kapatral|first8=Vinayak|date=2009-06-15|title=Comparative Genome-Scale Metabolic Reconstruction and Flux Balance Analysis of Multiple Staphylococcus aureus Genomes Identify Novel Antimicrobial Drug Targets|url=http://jb.asm.org/content/191/12/4015|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|language=en|volume=191|issue=12|pages=4015–4024|doi=10.1128/JB.01743-08|issn=0021-9193|pmc=2698402|pmid=19376871}}</ref> By performing in silico single and double gene deletions many enzymes essential to growth were identified.

{{About|the diagram used in systems engineering|the programmable logic controller language|Function block diagram}} [[Image:Functional_block_diagram_of_the_attitude_control_and_maneuvering_electronics_system.jpg|thumb|420px|Functional block diagram of the attitude control and maneuvering electronics system of the [[Project_Gemini#Spacecraft|Gemini spacecraft]]. June 1962.]] A '''functional block diagram''' in [[systems engineering]] and [[software engineering]] is a [[block diagram]]. It describes the functions and interrelationships of a [[system]].
The functional block diagram can picture:<ref>James Perozzo (1994) ''The complete guide to electronics troubleshooting''. p. 72</ref> * Functions of a system pictured by blocks * input and output elements of a block pictured with lines * the relationships between the functions, and * the functional sequences and paths for matter and or signals<ref>William H. Von Alven (1964) ''Reliability engineering'' explains: "Functional block diagrams show functional sequences and signal paths, and items which are wired in parallel are drawn in parallel" (p. 286)</ref> The block diagram can use additional schematic symbols to show particular properties.
Functional block diagrams have been used in a wide range applications, from [[systems engineering]] to [[software engineering]], since the late 1950s. They became a necessity in complex systems design to "understand thoroughly from exterior design the operation of the present system and the relationship of each of the parts to the whole."<ref>[[Harry H. Goode]], [[Robert Engel Machol]] (1957) System engineering: an introduction to the design of large-scale systems. p. 306</ref>
Many specific types of functional block diagrams have emerged. For example, the [[functional flow block diagram]] is a combination of the functional block diagram and the [[flow chart]]. Many software development methodologies are built with specific functional block diagram techniques. An example from the field of industrial computing is the [[Function Block Diagram]] (FBD), a graphical language for the design of [[programmable logic controller]]s.
==See also== * [[Function model]] * [[Functional flow block diagram]]
